items.body_markdown:
I do have a Spring Boot Application which uses custom context.xml for the tomcat. 
The context.xml contains property, defining the spring active profile
```
<Context>
    <Environment name="spring.profiles.active" value="profileName" type="java.lang.String" override="false" />
</Context>
```
File location is the /src/main/webapps/META-INF
I was expecting that after the file is deployed to the tomcat, context xml will be automatically picked by tomcat and thrown to the conf/catalina/localhost/

As it turned out, the war was deployed, but the conf/catalina/localhost stayed empty. 

After reading the docs i've found out that the server.xml has to be updated with the copyXML parameter as Host container.
The documentation says:
> copyXML
>Set to true if you want a context XML descriptor embedded inside the application (located at /META-INF/context.xml) to be copied to xmlBase when the application is deployed. On subsequent starts, the copied context XML descriptor will be used in preference to any context XML descriptor embedded inside the application even if the descriptor embedded inside the application is more recent. The flag's value defaults to false. Note if deployXML is false, this attribute will have no effect.

My Host looks like
```
<Host name="localhost"  appBase="webapps"
                  unpackWARs="true" autoDeploy="true" copyXML="true">
            </Host>
```

After restarting the server and redeploying the app, the /conf/Catalina/localhost still stayed empty.

Do you have any suggestions, what actions have to be taken in order to use custom context.xml?

answers.body_markdown:
Cmake is complaining about not finding a package configuration file (xxx.cmake), probably because you didn't build libmongoc/libbson.

I've tried to reproduce your issue and hit the same problem when I only installed them (apt-get install), so my suggestion is that you get the sources and build them as described at: http://mongoc.org/libmongoc/current/installing.html

Here's the list of commands (with the latest version of mongo-c-driver=1.15.1) which I just tried and worked fine:

    wget https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-c-driver/releases/download/1.15.1/mongo-c-driver-1.15.1.tar.gz
    tar xzf mongo-c-driver-1.15.1.tar.gz
    cd mongo-c-driver-1.15.1
    mkdir cmake-build
    cd cmake-build
    cmake -DENABLE_AUTOMATIC_INIT_AND_CLEANUP=OFF ..
    make
    sudo make install

At this point you can go back into mongocxx/build and run again the command you were stuck at:

    cd ../../mongo-cxx-driver/build
    cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local ..
answers.title: install MongoDB C++ Driver problem in ubuntu 16.04

answers.title: Selenium - Click on an item with text

answers.body_markdown:
Text() TEST.SER and class="search-choice-close" are not in same hierarchy so the option 1 would not work.

option 2 hierarchy created by your locator is wrong. span is above a tag

option 3 you are trying to click on the li element instead of the href. So it would not work.

Try By.XPATH(//a[@class='search-choice-close']/parent::span[contains(text(),'TEST.SER')]) if you want to click on the text.

If you want to click on the image just use By.XPATH(//a[@class='search-choice-close'])
answers.title: Selenium - Click on an item with text

answers.body_markdown:
The reason your xpaths are not finding the correct element is because they are looking for attributes of both the span and a tags either as if they were the same element, or as if one was imbedded inside of the other. You will need to instead find the span element, and then find the sibling a element that follows it.


Reasons for your issues:

    "test2": (By.XPATH, "//a[@class='search-choice-close' and contains(text(), 'TEST.SER')]")

Here you are looking for an a element that contains the proper class of the a element, but the text of the span element

    "test3": (By.XPATH, "//a[@class='search-choice-close']//span[contains(text(),'TEST.SER')]")

Here you are looking for the span element as if it existed within the a element, but it does not exist within the a element, but along side it

    "test": (By.XPATH,"//li[@class='search-choice']//span[contains(text(),'TEST.SER')]//a[ @class ='search-choice-close']")

Here you are doing the same as above, looking for an a element within the span element. The elements are not descendants or ancestors of each other, but rather siblings.

What you need to do is find the sibling element to the span element, if you need to look for the a element using the text of the span before it. 

    //span[text()='TEST.SER']/following::a


Here is some more information on the hierarchy of elements in the DOM that might be useful for you to go over the next time you are having issues locating elements through Xpath.
https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xpath_nodes.asp
answers.title: Selenium - Click on an item with text

answers.body_markdown:
The problem you are having is because the value `[null]` you are passing to the `iteratees` argument (the second one) does not match the signature of the function.

The `iteratees` argument is [documented][1] to be of type `(Array[]|Function[]|Object[]|string[])`.

To fix your call, just replace the second argument with `[_.identity]`, which is the default value, or alternatively set the second argument to `undefined`, which will also trigger the use of the default value. Check out the [MDN Docs on Default Parameters][2]. 


  [1]: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#orderBy

I got this code from python mailing list.Friends thanks for all your support and help

    import tkinter as tk
    
    class App(tk.Tk):
        def __init__(self,*args, **kwargs):
             tk.Tk.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
             self.label = tk.Label(self, text="", width=20, anchor="w")
             self.label.pack(side="top",fill="both",expand=True)
             self.print_label_slowly("Hello, world!")
    
        def print_label_slowly(self, message):
             '''Print a label one character at a time using the event loop'''
             t = self.label.cget("text")
             t += message[0]
             self.label.config(text=t)
             if len(message) > 1:
                 self.after(500, self.print_label_slowly, message[1:])
    
    app = App()
    app.mainloop()

So finally I have used this super library called gensim to generate the similarity.

```
import gensim
from nltk.tokenize import word_tokenize

def getSimilarityScore(raw_documents, words):
    gen_docs = [[w.lower() for w in word_tokenize(text)] 
            for text in raw_documents]
    dictionary = gensim.corpora.Dictionary(gen_docs)
    corpus = [dictionary.doc2bow(gen_doc) for gen_doc in gen_docs]
    tf_idf = gensim.models.TfidfModel(corpus)
    sims = gensim.similarities.Similarity('/usr/workdir',tf_idf[corpus],
                                      num_features=len(dictionary))
    
    query_doc_bow = dictionary.doc2bow(words)
    query_doc_tf_idf = tf_idf[query_doc_bow]
    
    return sims[query_doc_tf_idf]
```

You can use this method as:

```

Sentences = ["This is the most beautiful place in the world.",
            "This man has more skills to show in cricket than any other game.",
            "Hi there! how was your ladakh trip last month?",
            "Isn’t cricket supposed to be a team sport? I feel people should decide first whether cricket is a team game or an individual sport."]
    
words = ["cricket","sports","team","play","match"]

words_lower = [w.lower() for w in words]

getSimilarityScore(Sentences,words_lower)
```

answers.body_markdown:
You should generally avoid parsing arbitrary string input from users. Usually, this can be avoided by appropriate software design.

Anyway, just extract the language from the expression:

    make_function(alist(a = 1, b = 2), parse(text = 'a^b')[[1]])

**Edit:**

Just to show how you can check against a whitelist (no regex involved):

    whitelist <- c("+", "*", "-", "/", "^", "**", "%%", "%/%", "sin", "cos", "tan", "abs") #etc.
    expr <- parse(text = "cos(x)^sin(x)*abs(x)")
    foo <- function(e) if (length(e) > 1) lapply(as.list(e), foo) else return(e)
    funs <- unlist(foo(expr[[1]]))
    funs <- funs[vapply(funs, function(x) {x <- eval(x); is.function(x) | is.primitive(x)}, FUN.VALUE = TRUE)]
    all(vapply(funs, function(x) as.character(x) %in% whitelist, FUN.VALUE = TRUE))

Parsing and evaluating arbitrary code in a public shiny app is a security risk. This check ensures that only a predefined set of functions can be used. If you don't shy away from smaller risks, you could just use a blacklist instead (prohibiting functions like `system`, `system2`, `shell` etc.).

answers.body_markdown:
Parallel computing comes never for free. The new processes need to be created and the results need to be sent around the processes. Python loops are slow in comparison with loops written in C, as you can use them in numpy. Parallel computing is only helping for large problems that cannot be optimized in another way. Your example is so simple, working in parallel will not speed your problem up in comparison to:

```python
a = np.random.sample(n)
c = a ** a
```
answers.title: python multiprocessing pool run slower?

answers.body_markdown:
The problem is that multiprocessing need to serialise data to send it between processes, so as result if our computations are small, multiprocess program will be slower than single process.

You can do the following to prove that multiprocess program is faster, create function which sum square of number in range 10000000 (or even more) and run the function several times in one process program, then split work between processes.

```
def heavy_load(n):   # take really big n value like 10000000 
    _sum = 0
    for i in range(n):
        _sum += i**2
```

Local files can be used as sources in structured streaming, e.g.:
```python
stream = spark.readStream.schema(mySchema).option("maxFilesPerTrigger", 1).json("/my/data")
```
With this you can experiment on data transformation and output very easily, and there are many sample datasets online, e.g. on [kaggle][1]

If you want to have something production-like, twitter api is a good option. You will need some sort of a messaging middleware though, like Kafka or Azure Event Hub - a simple app can send tweets there and you will be able to pick them up easily from Spark. You can also generate data yourself on the input side instead of depending on Twitter.

answers.title: Jmeter-5.0 : Are RPS (Request per second) and TPS (Transaction per sec) same?

answers.body_markdown:
The difference between requests per second and transactions per second is that a transaction might consist of several requests.
In JMeter a transaction is - pretty obviously - represented by a [Transaction Controller](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/component_reference.html#Transaction_Controller).

To illustrate that:

- open your Chrome (or browser of choice)
- open the devtools (F12 in chrome)
- select the network tab
- browse to https://www.google.com

Whereas your transaction is "Open Google Landing Page" your browser performs over a dozen single requests.

If you want to generate a certain amount of requests (or transactions?) have a look at [JMeter Timers](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/component_reference.html#timers). The [Constant Throughput Timer](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/component_reference.html#Constant_Throughput_Timer) might be a good start! Please be aware, that the scope of the timer matters!

As I understand, you run the same program (`admin.runAsAdmin()`), but you don't close the non-admin one. Use `quit()` or `sys.exit()` for that.
Hope that's helpful!
answers.title: Two instances of tkinter window created when run python script as administrator

answers.body_markdown:
Perhaps I already found my answer.

I noticed the following line in the documentation of the [`DO`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/sql-do.html) command (in the "Description" section):

> The code block is treated as though it were the body of a function with no parameters, returning void. It is parsed and executed a single time.

So that seems to imply that the `DO` command officially does not (and will not) support the use of parameters. If that assumption is correct, and if there is no alternative for `DO`, I guess there are no straightforward options for executing anonymous parameterized PL/pgSQL code blocks from a client application.

I also found this [answer on dba.stackexchange.com](https://dba.stackexchange.com/a/240542). Reading that answer supports my suspicions about the failing of parsing parameters in the code block of a `DO` command:

> [The manual for psql:](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/app-psql.html#APP-PSQL-INTERPOLATION)

> > Variable interpolation will not be performed within quoted SQL literals and identifiers.

> The body of a DO statement (or function) is a quoted literal. Dollar-quoted in this case, but all the same...

Reading the rest of that answer, I become quite unhappy. I surely don't want to write my own parameter-parsing and dynamic SQL generation code (which seems to be implied in that answer when I try to apply it to my issue at hand). Imo, that would be like reinventing the wheel.

So, as it seems to me for now, defining and using (named) functions (or [temporary functions](https://stackoverflow.com/a/9981540/4174789)) might be the easiest and most straightforward way to work with procedural code (like PL/pgSQL) in PostgreSQL.

answers.title: Python extract json structure from html page

answers.body_markdown:
- If you just wanted to know how to access the egressURL, title and the type. You might just wanna read the answer below! Be careful however, cause the following code won't work unless you converted your HTML file *reddit_data* in something like a dictionnary ( Modified *shaik moeed*'s answer a tiny bit to also return title and type) :
```
[(i['egressUrl'], i['title'], i['type']) for i in reddit_data['dealDetails'].keys()]
```

 - However, If I got it right, the part you're missing is the conversion from HTML to a JSON friendly file. What I personally use, even though it's quite unpopular, is the **eval** function
```
dictionnary = eval(reddit_data)
```
This will convert the whole file into a dictionnary, I recommend that you only use it on the part of the text that 'looks' like a dictionnary! (One of the reason eval is unpopular, is because it won't convert strings like 'true'/'false' to Python's True/False, be careful with that :) )
Hope that helped!

answers.title: How to put on hold all other httpclient API request until main API request is finished and resume other hold API request?
How to put on hold all other httpclient API request until main API request is finished and resume other hold API request?

answers.body_markdown: In your _layout component template, create an ng-container tag and put all your child component tags inside the  ng-container. Now you can have an ngIf on the ng-container tag to not render the child components if main api has not given response yet. This way the child components Api will not get triggered. Hope this helps.
